answer_html: \(\left.\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}\right|_{x=1,y=2}=-\frac{3}{4}\) and so we conclude that the y-coordinate is changing at -3/4 kilometers per minute at that moment.
answer_latex:
$\left.\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}\right|_{x=1,y=2}=-\frac{3}{4}$ and so we conclude that the y-coordinate is changing at -3/4 kilometers
per minute at that moment.
hints_html:
Here x and y are functions of time, so we have the implicit relation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x(t)^2+2y(t)^2=9.\end{aligned}\]

Use implicit differentiation!
hints_raw:
Here x and y are functions of time, so we have the '''implicit relation'''

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x(t)^2+2y(t)^2=9.
</math>
Use implicit differentiation!
question: 1 (j)
sols_html:
We have that

\[\begin{aligned} x(t)^2+2y(t)^2=9\end{aligned}\]

and we want to find dy/dt when x=1, y=2 and dx/dt=3. Therefore, we implicitly differentiate and isolate for dy/dt,

\[\begin{aligned} 2x\frac{\textrm{d}x}{\textrm{d}t}+4y\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}&=0\\ \frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}&=-\frac{x}{2y}\frac{\textrm{d}x}{\textrm{d}t}.\end{aligned}\]

We then sub in x=1, y=2, and dx/dt=3 to get that

\[\begin{aligned} \left.\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}\right|_{x=1,y=2}=-\frac{1}{4}(3)=-\frac{3}{4}\end{aligned}\]

and so we conclude that the y-coordinate is changing at -3/4 kilometers per minute at that moment.
sols_raw:
We have that

:<math>
x(t)^2+2y(t)^2=9
</math>

and we want to find dy/dt when x=1, y=2 and dx/dt=3.  Therefore, we implicitly differentiate and isolate for dy/dt,

:<math>
\begin{align}
2x\frac{\textrm{d}x}{\textrm{d}t}+4y\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}&=0\\
\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}&=-\frac{x}{2y}\frac{\textrm{d}x}{\textrm{d}t}.
\end{align}
</math>

We then sub in x=1, y=2, and dx/dt=3 to get that

:<math>
\left.\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}\right|_{x=1,y=2}=-\frac{1}{4}(3)=-\frac{3}{4}
</math>

and so we conclude that the y-coordinate is changing at -3/4 kilometers per minute at that moment.
statement_html:
A racing car travels along the ellipse

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x^2+2y^2=9\end{aligned}\]

where x and y are measured in kilometers. When the car is at the point (1,2), the x-coordinate of the point is changing at the rate of 3 kilometers per minute. How fast is the y-coordinate changing at that moment?
statement_latex:
A racing car travels along the ellipse

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}x^2+2y^2=9
\end{align*}

where x and y are measured in kilometers. When the car is at the point
(1,2), the x-coordinate of the point is changing at the rate of 3
kilometers per minute. How fast is the y-coordinate changing at that
moment?
statement_raw:
A racing car travels along the ellipse

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x^2+2y^2=9
</math>

where x and y are measured in kilometers.  When the car is at the point (1,2), the x-coordinate of the point is changing at the rate of 3 kilometers per minute.  How fast is the y-coordinate changing at that moment?
